newsitem.title: UK: GDR REPORT - India up, Taiwan retreats.
newsitem.headline: GDR REPORT - India up, Taiwan retreats.

text.p: Indian Global Depositary Receipts posted further gains on Friday, driven by a strong local market and tight supply, dealers said.
"India is firm but the market is illiquid. Prices can run up very easily," a trader said.
Traders expect a generally positive outlook ahead of the budget on February 28, with the local market seen rallying in speculative trade in coming weeks.
GDRs should make ground on the back of the local market, but some traders warn that current high premiums to local prices are due to ease.
Traders reported selling in East India and interest in SBI.
EIH was unchanged at $19.00/$20.00 and SBI added 96 cents to $20.50/$21.50.
But they said gains made by the end of the month were at risk if the budget contained few positive developments.
"The interesi in India is speculative with little FII demand. Some people are saying they don't see a good budget," a dearler said.
The Bombay Stock Exchange's (BSE) benchmark 30-share index rose 29.34 points, or 0.84 percent, to 3,521.99.
The Indian GDR index JCEAI closed at 72.25, up 1.25 points or 1.77 percent with the premium over the local market at 19.01 percent from 17.99 percent on Friday.
Taiwanese GDRs fell back after a strong Thursday showing. Traders said the Taiwanese market had run out of steam after an eqight day rally.
But a recovery in chip prices boded well longer term for the key electronics sector.
The Taiwan GDR Index closed at 104.50, down 1.98 points or 1.86 percent, a premium of 3.85 percent against 5.20 percent on Thursday.
The Taiwan Weighted Index shed 36.77 points, or 0.49 percent, to 7,499.51.
The Capel Korea GDR Index ended at 67.07 points, up 0.16 points or 0.24 percent and the premium at 43.29 percent over the local market.
The Korea Composite Index made 4.29 points to 721, a 0.6 percent rise.
